title: ‘Unacceptable’: What Jaylen Brown, NBA official had to say about controversial moment in Celtics’ loss
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Jaylen Brown criticized referees after Celtics' 105-103 loss to the Jazz, citing a crucial non-call on a potential foul.
Referee Kevin Scott defended the non-call, stating both players slipped, nullifying any foul involving Jaylen Brown and Keyonte George.
Brown may face league action for his remarks, expressing disbelief at officials' claim they didn't see the alleged foul.

title: Moving to Massachusetts isn’t easy — when did you finally feel at home?
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Hayley Perry-Sanchez moved to Cambridge for her husband's Harvard MBA, facing difficulties with weather and high living costs.
Living conditions included a $3,350/month rental with communal laundry and no dishwasher, increasing financial challenges on student loans.
Perry-Sanchez connected to Massachusetts through local craft stores, documenting her experiences on TikTok and building a community.

title: Parts of Morrissey Blvd. may close this week due to high tide flooding
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Morrissey Blvd. may close Tuesday to Sunday due to high tide flooding, warns Mass. Department of Conservation & Recreation.
DCR may close the road from Freeport Street to Bianculli Boulevard if flooding occurs near UMass Boston.
High tides expected to reach about 12 feet daily from November 4 to November 9, potentially causing closures.

title: Voting guide: Here’s what voters need to know before Boston’s Tuesday election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Polling stations in Boston are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. across 275 precincts for the Tuesday election.
Mayor Michelle Wu is unopposed; voters will decide on Boston City Council's four at-large seats and contested district seats.
Ballots available in multiple languages; mail-in ballots must be returned to drop boxes or City Hall, not polling places.

title: The Bruins’ second line is looking like a difference-maker, in more ways than one
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins' second line, featuring Pavel Zacha, Casey Mittelstadt, and Viktor Arvidsson, is driving offensive success.
Casey Mittelstadt has tallied six points in seven games since returning from being benched, boosting the second line's performance.
Coach Marco Sturm's strategy of benching players for performance improvement has led to increased production from the Bruins' lineup.

title: Garrett Crochet, Roman Anthony named finalists for Cy Young, Rookie of the Year awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox pitcher Garrett Crochet is a finalist for the AL Cy Young Award after leading the league in innings and strikeouts.
Crochet posted an 18-5 record with a 2.59 ERA, helping the Red Sox secure a playoff victory over the Yankees.
Red Sox rookie Roman Anthony is nominated for AL Rookie of the Year after a strong 71-game performance with a .292 average.

title: Ranking top priorities for Patriots at NFL trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots face key decisions at the NFL trade deadline, focusing on edge rushers and depth in several positions.
Running back and edge rusher are primary trade targets due to injuries and inconsistent pass rush performance.
Secondary concerns include bolstering the depth at cornerback, linebacker, and possibly acquiring a standout wide receiver.

title: Patriots’ pass-protection issues are mounting as Drake Maye ties worrisome stat from last year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The Patriots have given up 34 sacks this season, the second-most in the NFL.
Drake Maye's offensive line faced 12 sacks in the last two games, raising protection concerns.
Patriots center Garrett Bradbury admits the team's need to improve their pass-blocking strategy.

title: Downtown Boston hotel settles discrimination complaint after woman was accused of being a man
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Liberty Hotel in Boston settles with state after staff accused Ansley Baker of being a man in the women's restroom.
The settlement includes a $10,000 donation to an LGBTQIA2S+ charity and updates to the hotel's non-discrimination policies.
Baker plans to file a civil lawsuit for punitive damages; the hotel suspended the security guard involved in the incident.

title: Falcons coach walks back ‘clapgate’ accusations after Patriots push back
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Falcons coach Raheem Morris walked back accusations that the Patriots simulated Atlanta's snap count in a 24-23 loss.
Morris initially claimed Patriots mimicked QB Michael Penix Jr.'s clapping, leading to an intentional grounding penalty.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel dismissed the 'clapgate' allegations, noting no evidence of intentional simulation by his team.
